_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

WestFarm Foods produces a full line of dairy-based and other products for the consumer, commodity and specialty markets. With plants located in Washington, Oregon, Idaho and California, the company serves western, national, and international markets, depending on product type.  As stated on their website, "Founded by five Puget Sound cooperatives in 1918 as the United Dairymen's Association, the company eventually grew to include dairy associations throughout Washington, Oregon, Northern California and Idaho. Renamed WestFarm Foods in 1999, the company is one of the largest dairy products processors in the U.S. with annual sales of over $1.3 billion. The Seattle-based company currently operates eleven plants serving over 700 dairy farm families."

WestFarm Food's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The facility maintains a Safety Committee whose members are the designated incident commanders for the facility.  WestFarm Foods has an Emergency Response Plan (Plan) in effect, which is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM document maintained at the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The facility is located at 4058 Rainier Avenue South, Seattle, Washington 98118.  The milk plant was built in 1962 with new ammonia refrigeration system equipment and co

mponents.  The ice cream plant was added shortly after with a new low stage system.  Subsequent modifications have included:

1990  Accumulator 2 and the Gram Freezers added.
1991  Accumulator 7 and the Gram Rice added.
1992  Booster 5 added.
1996  Additional Condenser and North Dock Evaporator added.
1997  Old Condenser equipment removed.
2000  Receiver and Blowmold chiller upgraded.
2003  Pit Accumulator upgraded.

The ammonia refrigeration system was designed and constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the following:  Uniform Building Code; ANSI 39.1, 1971, pg. 15 (Vessels); and ASME, Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII.

The two ammonia refrigeration systems (Milk and Ice Cream) use a total of approximately 24,000 pounds of ammonia to provide cooling for process areas, milk/ice cream storage, and freezers.  The majority of the systems including vessels and compressors are located in two engine rooms.  The condensers are mounted on the roof of the building, and all of the evaporators are located in their respective cold/freezer storage rooms/areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

WestFarm Food's Milk and Ice Cream ammonia refrigeration systems have many safety features.  Much of the safety associated with the systems is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the systems.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.

Other safety features of the ammonia refrigeration system include: an ammonia sensor that sounds a facility-wide alarm, an emergency shut down button that kills power to the engine room equipment, relief valves on all pressure vessels, continuous ventilation in the main engine room to prevent ammonia explosions.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility has based its maintenance program on the industry standard: the International Institute of

Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems" is used at the facility.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An investigation into the WestFarm Foods facility accident history during the Process Hazard Analysis (July 22nd  and 23rd, 2003), revealed that there have been no reportable ammonia related accidents, incidents or releases at the facility over the past five years (May 1999 - May 2004.)

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The WestFarm Foods facility has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document, which is maintained at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

  1.)  To save lives.
  2.)  To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.)  To protect the environment.
  4.)  To minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes due to the renovation of the facility.  Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures and the Emergency Response Team holds regular drills.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

In June 1999, the Milk and Ice Cream Plant refrigeration systems were thoroughly examined for safety hazards by way of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  The PHA generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the WestFarm Foods facility located at 4058 Rainier Avenue South, Seattle, Washington 98118.  In addition, a new Process Hazard Analysis was conducted in July 2

003 to further improve the safety of the facility.  The 2003 PHA consisted of a:

? Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study;
? series of safety checklists; and
? facility inspection.

The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The WestFarm Foods Safety Committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, by June 2004, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.
